The Podcats website is a very simple design and that is on purpose. On top of that, the style of the site is separated from the content. The upshot of that is that redesigning the site is as simple as replacing the stylesheet with a new one. The skill, therefore, lies in creating the stylesheet to turn a dull site interesting; and to create the site properly so that new stylesheets work with it.

Simplicity

Have a look at this site. Now have a look at it without CSS. Our websites follow the same design principles. By keeping the site as simple as possible we can make the design fit your needs and alter it to keep up with your site changing.

The ease with which we can change the design to keep up with your site's evolving is the obvious benefit to simplicity but there are others. Consider Podcats itself. As a blog site, Podcats is likely to be visited by more than just people at home on their computers with their browsers. Some people may visit from a smartphone or an old not-so-smart phone. Because the content of the site is often changing, some people may wish to use an RSS feed to be notified of when new content arrives. Some people may be using a braille reader or have altered their browser to make the text bigger or the contrast stronger. Some people may be using screen readers. Still more people may wish to print it before reading it.

All of these are valid ways of viewing a website. The more your own website can support, the more people your website is accessible to. The more diverse the ways you can view the website, the more people it is accessible to. And, of course, the more you make your site accessible to people who have difficulties, the more respect you, as a company, will get. The easier it is to navigate your site, the more the users of your site will appreciate it and enjoy using it. Already we see how keeping your site simple can aid people but really not detract from the site at all.

All Podcats websites are designed to be accessible by as many people as possible, and we do this by keeping the site simple and effective.

Usability

Podcats believe that information overload is the bane of the internet. Too often you come across websites with too much information on one page, or some flashy animated graphics that are all very well and good but completely obfuscate the site's navigation.

Our site designs are therefore oriented around providing the information the user came for, and a bit around it to help the user to get to other information. The user's experience when they visit the site is not, as you may think, affected by the way the site looks, but it is affected by how easily the website tells them what they need to know without them having to work for the information. Every site has a purpose: if that purpose is not the first thing the user sees, then no amount of fancy design is going to make them think it is a good website. The most basic website has a completely default design, like the one we linked in the second paragraph on this page, but if it tells you what you want to know, it is already an infinitely better design than any website with a good colour scheme and no clear purpose.

Standards

Many people do not appreciate how important it is to stick to standards when developing web applications. Just because Microsoft have the biggest market share of Internet browsers doesn't mean it's OK to just target them. It makes sense if you consider that the people who do not use Internet Explorer are the people who are more internet-savvy, because they are the people who have understood why not to use Internet Explorer in the first place. If you make your site unusable to these people, the negative rap you get from their bad experiences will weigh heavily on your site and your company as a whole.

Standards compliance ensures that your website will look and work exactly the same on everyone's browser. It also ensures that specialised browsers like braille or screen readers can cope with the site, because you will not have used any strange, unsupported features.

All Podcats websites are W3C compliant, and this can be seen by the W3C logo present on all our pages. W3C is the organisation that defines the web standards.

Podcats Web Design

A Podcats website is therefore three things. First, it is simple. It is simple so that anyone can use it, and it can be used through any means. It is simple so that if you, as a customer, want a redesign, we can do it at a lower cost to you, and the original site itself is similarly a much lower investment.

Secondly, it is usable. It has a purpose and it is not embarrassed to show it. It does not overload the user with unnecessary information or make it difficult for them to even find the information they need.

Thirdly, it is standards compliant. This means that whoever uses it now or in the future, or even people using past technology that has served them well for years, will have the same experience.

Technology

At Podcats we are committed to using the best technology that money can buy. Luckily for you, as a consumer, the best technology that money can buy is, in fact, completely free. The only things that cost money are hardware and domain names. Of course, web space uses up hardware because disk space is a real, physical thing, so that costs money too. But the things we use to build the site itself are free, and hence we can deliver a site to you at only labour costs.

Many people who use the internet have never heard of open-source technology, or simply don't trust it, but at Podcats we have complete faith in it. Many of the Podcats themselves are contributors to open-source projects, and since most Podcats are Perl developers, they use open-source technology to contribute to open-source projects.

The Podcats website itself is running on completely open-source software. The web server runs Debian Linux (debian.org). The pages are served to you by Apache web server. The blog is powered by Blosxom, which is written in Perl, which is itself written in C (Wikipedia entry). JavaScript, HTML, CSS, RSS - these are all open standards. Absolutely nothing is proprietary. We have not paid for a single licence because we have used no technology that requires us to do so. All that was paid for were the domain name and the web space to run the site on.

Many people have put time and effort into making all these technologies reliable and secure, from both intrusion and malicious software, and ask for no payment. We at Podcats are only too happy to accept their offerings and put them to good use by helping people who need a good website to get one without huge investment that they simply cannot afford.

I want one of those

If you'd like us to design you a website then simply email al @ podcats.in. Your email should include the purpose of the website and the things you want in it. You should also decide whether you want us to find you web hosting or whether you already have some, and the same applies to the domain name itself.

Here's a quick checklist of things that you should have at least thought about before you email us, since these are the things we will at some point need to know before we can give you a definite price.

  • The name and purpose of your website. This should be succinct: a website with more than one purpose is more than one website
  • Your target audience. This will influence the styles we give it.
  • Features you want. For example, you might want a message board or a blog, or some way of syndicating content.
  • A timescale. The same amount of work done in a shorter time will cost more, because things tend to take as long as they take and rushing them is a bad idea.
